div.p: A radiation oncology procedure. If the treatment is part of a larger course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should indicate that.

description.value: A radiation oncology procedure. If the treatment is part of a larger course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should indicate that.

definition.value: A radiation oncology procedure. If the treatment is part of a larger course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should indicate that.

short.value: Elements that belong to all information items.

definition.value: Elements that belong to all information items.

short.value: A human language, spoken or written.

definition.value: A human language, spoken or written.

short.value: A set of rules under which this content was created

definition.value: A set of rules under which this content was created

short.value: A human-readable narrative, potentially including images, that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human.

definition.value: A human-readable narrative, potentially including images, that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human.

short.value: A state that relates to the workflow or interpretation of this resource. Certain status values can modify the meaning of the resource, for example, entered-in-error. When a boolean value is used, Status of true indicates the record is active, false means inactive.

definition.value: A state that relates to the workflow or interpretation of this resource. Certain status values can modify the meaning of the resource, for example, entered-in-error. When a boolean value is used, Status of true indicates the record is active, false means inactive.

short.value: Captures the reason for the current state of the procedure.

definition.value: Captures the reason for the current state of the procedure.

short.value: Business identifier or external id for this resource.

definition.value: Business identifier or external id for this resource.

short.value: The subject of a clinical statement, often called the Patient or the Subject. The SubjectOfRecord typically identifies the clinical record in which this statement is contained. If the statement should be in John Doe's patient record, then John Doe is the subject of record. When there is no patient, the SubjectOfRecord can also be a location, group, or other entity that statement pertains to. For example, observations concerning a hospital ward would have a Location as the SubjectOfRecord.

definition.value:
The subject of a clinical statement, often called the Patient or the Subject. The SubjectOfRecord typically identifies the clinical record in which this statement is contained. If the statement should be in John Doe's patient record, then John Doe is the subject of record. When there is no patient, the SubjectOfRecord can also be a location, group, or other entity that statement pertains to. For example, observations concerning a hospital ward would have a Location as the SubjectOfRecord.
Note that the word 'Subject' is used here in the sense of a person or entity subjected to observations or actions, not subject as in a conceptual topic, like heart disease.

short.value: The encounter or episode of care

definition.value: The encounter or episode of care

short.value: The point in time when the statement was created.

definition.value: The point in time when the statement was created.

short.value: The explanation or justification for the current item or action, as a code.

definition.value: The explanation or justification for the current item or action, as a code. Reason is a string or CodeableConcept in DSTU2 but in later versions only a CodeableConcept.

short.value: The justification that the procedure was performed.

definition.value: The justification that the procedure was performed.

short.value: A condition that is or may be present in a subject. 'Condition' is interpreted broadly and could be a disorder, abnormality, problem, injury, complaint, functionality, illness, disease, ailment, sickness, affliction, upset, difficulty, disorder, symptom, worry, or trouble.

definition.value: A condition that is or may be present in a subject. 'Condition' is interpreted broadly and could be a disorder, abnormality, problem, injury, complaint, functionality, illness, disease, ailment, sickness, affliction, upset, difficulty, disorder, symptom, worry, or trouble. The Observation-based class, ConditionAbsent, should be used to describe conditions that are not present or negative findings. SHR Condition uses the SHR BodyLocation structure that includes not only a code, but optional laterality, direction, clock direction, and distance. If included, the distance is measured from the location specified by the code, laterality, and direction.

short.value: Represents the result of evaluations (measurements, tests, or questions) that have been performed.

definition.value: Represents the result of evaluations (measurements, tests, or questions) that have been performed. Observation has a value representing the result (answer), or an DataAbsentReason indicating why the value is not present. Things observed about the subject can include social and behavioral factors, subjective and objective observations, and assessments. For an Observation, the Code describes the aspect or property of the subject being observed or measured. The Code is the 'question code' that pairs to the 'answer' contained in the Value.

short.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

definition.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

short.value: A reference to a document, used to describe a document that is made available to a healthcare system. A document is some sequence of bytes that is identifiable, establishes its own context (e.g., what subject, author, etc. can be displayed to the user), and has defined update management. The DocumentReference resource can be used with any document format that has a recognized mime type and that conforms to this definition.

definition.value: A reference to a document, used to describe a document that is made available to a healthcare system. A document is some sequence of bytes that is identifiable, establishes its own context (e.g., what subject, author, etc. can be displayed to the user), and has defined update management. The DocumentReference resource can be used with any document format that has a recognized mime type and that conforms to this definition.

short.value: A request for this procedure.

definition.value: A request for this procedure.

short.value: A request for a procedure to be performed. May be a proposal or an order.

definition.value: A request for a procedure to be performed. May be a proposal or an order.

short.value: Used to record and send details about a request for referral service or transfer of a patient to the care of another provider or provider organization.

definition.value: Used to record and send details about a request for referral service or transfer of a patient to the care of another provider or provider organization.

short.value: A record of a request for service such as diagnostic investigations, treatments, or operations to be performed.

definition.value: A record of a request for service such as diagnostic investigations, treatments, or operations to be performed.

short.value: The point or period of time when the event takes place. Times can be precise (dateTime) or approximate (date). If a time period is used, and the start date or dateTime is missing, the start of the period is not known. If the end date or dateTime is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.

definition.value: The point or period of time when the event takes place. Times can be precise (dateTime) or approximate (date). If a time period is used, and the start date or dateTime is missing, the start of the period is not known. If the end date or dateTime is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.

short.value: Record of someone or something involvement in an activity or event.

definition.value: Record of someone or something involvement in an activity or event.

short.value: Constrains participants to classes that are accepted by FHIR as actors in procedures in STU 3.

definition.value: Constrains participants to classes that are accepted by FHIR as actors in procedures in STU 3.

short.value: The role played by the participant engaged in the action, for example, as the attending physician, surgical assistant, etc.

definition.value: The role played by the participant engaged in the action, for example, as the attending physician, surgical assistant, etc.

short.value: The point in time or span of time the participant is involved.

definition.value: The point in time or span of time the participant is involved.

short.value: The party represented by the actual participant.

definition.value: The party represented by the actual participant.

short.value: The technique used to carry out an action, for example, the specific imaging technical or assessment vehicle.

definition.value: The technique used to carry out an action, for example, the specific imaging technical or assessment vehicle.

short.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

definition.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

short.value: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. Body location is a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.

definition.value: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. Body location is a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases. + Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location. Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

definition.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

short.value: Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.

definition.value:
Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.
The laterality element is part of BodyLocation, a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type (a reusable structure), not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: Orientation of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location in another orientation.

definition.value:
Orientation of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location in another orientation. The orientation element is part of BodyLocation, a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type (a reusable structure), not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: The relationship between a landmark that helps determine a body location and the body location itself. The location relative to a landmark is specified by:

definition.value:
The relationship between a landmark that helps determine a body location and the body location itself. The location relative to a landmark is specified by: * Specifying the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, * Specifying the direction from the landmark to the body location, and * Specifying the distance from the landmark to the body location.
The RelationToLandmark element is part of BodyLocation, a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type (a reusable structure), not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: A larger event of which this particular procedure is a component or step.

definition.value: A larger event of which this particular procedure is a component or step.

short.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

definition.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

short.value: A record of the use of a medication. If the medication is given as part of a course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should refer to the CourseOfTreatment.

definition.value: A record of the use of a medication. If the medication is given as part of a course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should refer to the CourseOfTreatment. Although FHIR MedicationAdministration supports date of administration, information source, performer, it lacks common provenance elements, statement creation date, author, and recorder. These are supported as optional extensions. FHIR DSTU2 lacks a category attribute, which is provided as an extension in that version. SHR does not allow the 'not given' attributes from DSTU2 and STU3, since they are dropped in R4. The status element is used to document medications not given.

short.value: Represents the result of evaluations (measurements, tests, or questions) that have been performed.

definition.value: Represents the result of evaluations (measurements, tests, or questions) that have been performed. Observation has a value representing the result (answer), or an DataAbsentReason indicating why the value is not present. Things observed about the subject can include social and behavioral factors, subjective and objective observations, and assessments. For an Observation, the Code describes the aspect or property of the subject being observed or measured. The Code is the 'question code' that pairs to the 'answer' contained in the Value.

short.value: The general type or class of this item.

definition.value: The general type or class of this item.

short.value: An added or follow-up note, often after the fact, that contains metadata about who made the statement and when.

definition.value: An added or follow-up note, often after the fact, that contains metadata about who made the statement and when.

short.value: The purpose of a treatment.

definition.value: The purpose of a treatment.

short.value: Services and space and equipment provided for a particular purpose; a building or place that provides a particular service or is used for a particular industry. Could be a clinical site, community site, or a mobile facility.

definition.value: Services and space and equipment provided for a particular purpose; a building or place that provides a particular service or is used for a particular industry. Could be a clinical site, community site, or a mobile facility.

short.value: The result of an event or performance of an action or behavior, for example, an adverse reaction or procedure.

definition.value: The result of an event or performance of an action or behavior, for example, an adverse reaction or procedure.

short.value: Items used during procedure

definition.value: Items used during procedure

short.value: A device that is implanted, removed or otherwise manipulated (e.g., calibration, battery replacement, fitting a prosthesis, attaching a wound-vac, etc.) as a focal portion of the Procedure.

definition.value: A device that is implanted, removed or otherwise manipulated (e.g., calibration, battery replacement, fitting a prosthesis, attaching a wound-vac, etc.) as a focal portion of the Procedure.

short.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

definition.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

short.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

definition.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

short.value: A decimal value.

definition.value: A decimal value.

short.value: A code indicated if the value represents an upper or lower bound

definition.value: A code indicated if the value represents an upper or lower bound

short.value: The unit of measure of the quantity.

definition.value: The unit of measure of the quantity.

short.value: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)

definition.value: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

description.value: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

short.value: Additional Content defined by implementations

definition.value: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

comment.value: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

short.value: Identity of the terminology system

definition.value: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.

comment.value: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...). OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

requirements.value: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

short.value: Version of the system - if relevant

definition.value: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

comment.value: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

short.value: Symbol in syntax defined by the system

definition.value: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).

requirements.value: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

short.value: Representation defined by the system

definition.value: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.

requirements.value: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know the system.

map.value: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

short.value: If this coding was chosen directly by the user

definition.value: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).

comment.value: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.

requirements.value: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

map.value: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [ fhir:source "true"; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O ]

short.value: The total amount of radiation dose delivered for the course of therapy. (source: SNOMED, ASTRO)

definition.value: The total amount of radiation dose delivered for the course of therapy. (source: SNOMED, ASTRO)

However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

comment.value: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

definition.value: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).

requirements.value: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

short.value: Representation defined by the system

definition.value: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.

definition.value: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).

comment.value: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.

map.value: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [ fhir:source "true"; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O ]

short.value: A code explaining unplanned or premature termination of a plan of treatment, course of medication, or research study.

definition.value: A code explaining unplanned or premature termination of a plan of treatment, course of medication, or research study.
A radiation oncology procedure. If the treatment is part of a larger course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should indicate that.

definition.value: Elements that belong to all information items.

When there is no patient, the SubjectOfRecord can also be a location, group, or other entity that statement pertains to. For example, observations concerning a hospital ward would have a Location as the SubjectOfRecord.

definition.value:
The subject of a clinical statement, often called the Patient or the Subject. The SubjectOfRecord typically identifies the clinical record in which this statement is contained. If the statement should be in John Doe's patient record, then John Doe is the subject of record. When there is no patient, the SubjectOfRecord can also be a location, group, or other entity that statement pertains to. For example, observations concerning a hospital ward would have a Location as the SubjectOfRecord.
Note that the word 'Subject' is used here in the sense of a person or entity subjected to observations or actions, not subject as in a conceptual topic, like heart disease.

definition.value: The explanation or justification for the current item or action, as a code. Reason is a string or CodeableConcept in DSTU2 but in later versions only a CodeableConcept.

short.value: The justification that the procedure was performed.

definition.value: The justification that the procedure was performed.

short.value: A condition that is or may be present in a subject. 'Condition' is interpreted broadly and could be a disorder, abnormality, problem, injury, complaint, functionality, illness, disease, ailment, sickness, affliction, upset, difficulty, disorder, symptom, worry, or trouble.

'Condition' is interpreted broadly and could be a disorder, abnormality, problem, injury, complaint, functionality, illness, disease, ailment, sickness, affliction, upset, difficulty, disorder, symptom, worry, or trouble. The Observation-based class, ConditionAbsent, should be used to describe conditions that are not present or negative findings. SHR Condition uses the SHR BodyLocation structure that includes not only a code, but optional laterality, direction, clock direction, and distance. If included, the distance is measured from the location specified by the code, laterality, and direction.

Observation has a value representing the result (answer), or an DataAbsentReason indicating why the value is not present. Things observed about the subject can include social and behavioral factors, subjective and objective observations, and assessments. For an Observation, the Code describes the aspect or property of the subject being observed or measured. The Code is the 'question code' that pairs to the 'answer' contained in the Value.

short.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

A document is some sequence of bytes that is identifiable, establishes its own context (e.g., what subject, author, etc. can be displayed to the user), and has defined update management. The DocumentReference resource can be used with any document format that has a recognized mime type and that conforms to this definition.

definition.value: A reference to a document, used to describe a document that is made available to a healthcare system. A document is some sequence of bytes that is identifiable, establishes its own context (e.g., what subject, author, etc. can be displayed to the user), and has defined update management. The DocumentReference resource can be used with any document format that has a recognized mime type and that conforms to this definition.

short.value: A request for this procedure.

definition.value: A request for this procedure.

short.value: A request for a procedure to be performed. May be a proposal or an order.

definition.value: A request for a procedure to be performed. May be a proposal or an order.

short.value: Used to record and send details about a request for referral service or transfer of a patient to the care of another provider or provider organization.

definition.value: Used to record and send details about a request for referral service or transfer of a patient to the care of another provider or provider organization.

short.value: A record of a request for service such as diagnostic investigations, treatments, or operations to be performed.

definition.value: A record of a request for service such as diagnostic investigations, treatments, or operations to be performed.

short.value: The point or period of time when the event takes place. Times can be precise (dateTime) or approximate (date). If a time period is used, and the start date or dateTime is missing, the start of the period is not known. If the end date or dateTime is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.

definition.value: The point or period of time when the event takes place. Times can be precise (dateTime) or approximate (date). If a time period is used, and the start date or dateTime is missing, the start of the period is not known. If the end date or dateTime is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.

short.value: Record of someone or something involvement in an activity or event.

definition.value: Record of someone or something involvement in an activity or event.

short.value: Constrains participants to classes that are accepted by FHIR as actors in procedures in STU 3.

definition.value: Constrains participants to classes that are accepted by FHIR as actors in procedures in STU 3.

short.value: The role played by the participant engaged in the action, for example, as the attending physician, surgical assistant, etc.

definition.value: The role played by the participant engaged in the action, for example, as the attending physician, surgical assistant, etc.

short.value: The point in time or span of time the participant is involved.

definition.value: The point in time or span of time the participant is involved.

short.value: The party represented by the actual participant.

definition.value: The party represented by the actual participant.

short.value: The technique used to carry out an action, for example, the specific imaging technical or assessment vehicle.

definition.value: The technique used to carry out an action, for example, the specific imaging technical or assessment vehicle.

short.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

definition.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

short.value: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. Body location is a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.

definition.value: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. Body location is a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases. + Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location. Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

definition.value: The main type identifier for a lab, procedure, condition, etc., usually drawn from a controlled vocabulary.

short.value: Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.

definition.value:
Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.
The laterality element is part of BodyLocation, a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type (a reusable structure), not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: Orientation of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location in another orientation.

definition.value:
Orientation of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location in another orientation. The orientation element is part of BodyLocation, a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type (a reusable structure), not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: The relationship between a landmark that helps determine a body location and the body location itself. The location relative to a landmark is specified by:

definition.value:
The relationship between a landmark that helps determine a body location and the body location itself. The location relative to a landmark is specified by: * Specifying the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, * Specifying the direction from the landmark to the body location, and * Specifying the distance from the landmark to the body location.
The RelationToLandmark element is part of BodyLocation, a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location. + Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation. + Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by: - Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and - Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type (a reusable structure), not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: A larger event of which this particular procedure is a component or step.

definition.value: A larger event of which this particular procedure is a component or step.

short.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

definition.value: An action that is or was performed on or for a patient. This can be a physical intervention like an operation, or less invasive like long term services, counseling, or hypnotherapy.

short.value: A record of the use of a medication. If the medication is given as part of a course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should refer to the CourseOfTreatment.

definition.value: A record of the use of a medication. If the medication is given as part of a course of treatment, the PartOf attribute should refer to the CourseOfTreatment. Although FHIR MedicationAdministration supports date of administration, information source, performer, it lacks common provenance elements, statement creation date, author, and recorder. These are supported as optional extensions. FHIR DSTU2 lacks a category attribute, which is provided as an extension in that version. SHR does not allow the 'not given' attributes from DSTU2 and STU3, since they are dropped in R4. The status element is used to document medications not given.

short.value: Represents the result of evaluations (measurements, tests, or questions) that have been performed.

definition.value: Represents the result of evaluations (measurements, tests, or questions) that have been performed. Observation has a value representing the result (answer), or an DataAbsentReason indicating why the value is not present. Things observed about the subject can include social and behavioral factors, subjective and objective observations, and assessments. For an Observation, the Code describes the aspect or property of the subject being observed or measured. The Code is the 'question code' that pairs to the 'answer' contained in the Value.

short.value: The general type or class of this item.

definition.value: The general type or class of this item.

short.value: An added or follow-up note, often after the fact, that contains metadata about who made the statement and when.

definition.value: An added or follow-up note, often after the fact, that contains metadata about who made the statement and when.

short.value: The purpose of a treatment.

definition.value: The purpose of a treatment.

short.value: Services and space and equipment provided for a particular purpose; a building or place that provides a particular service or is used for a particular industry. Could be a clinical site, community site, or a mobile facility.

definition.value: Services and space and equipment provided for a particular purpose; a building or place that provides a particular service or is used for a particular industry. Could be a clinical site, community site, or a mobile facility.

short.value: The result of an event or performance of an action or behavior, for example, an adverse reaction or procedure.

definition.value: The result of an event or performance of an action or behavior, for example, an adverse reaction or procedure.

short.value: Items used during procedure

definition.value: Items used during procedure

short.value: A device that is implanted, removed or otherwise manipulated (e.g., calibration, battery replacement, fitting a prosthesis, attaching a wound-vac, etc.) as a focal portion of the Procedure.

definition.value: A device that is implanted, removed or otherwise manipulated (e.g., calibration, battery replacement, fitting a prosthesis, attaching a wound-vac, etc.) as a focal portion of the Procedure.

short.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

definition.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

short.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

definition.value: The total number of treatment sessions (fractions) administered during a course of radiation therapy therapy. A fraction is a portion of the total radiation dose, delivered as a series of treatments that make up the full course of radiotherapy. (source: LOINC)

short.value: A decimal value.

definition.value: A decimal value.

short.value: A code indicated if the value represents an upper or lower bound

definition.value: A code indicated if the value represents an upper or lower bound

short.value: The unit of measure of the quantity.

definition.value: The unit of measure of the quantity.

short.value: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)

definition.value: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

description.value: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

short.value: Additional Content defined by implementations

definition.value: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

comment.value: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

short.value: Identity of the terminology system

definition.value: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.

comment.value: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...). OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

requirements.value: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

short.value: Version of the system - if relevant

definition.value: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

comment.value: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

short.value: Symbol in syntax defined by the system

definition.value: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).

requirements.value: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

short.value: Representation defined by the system

definition.value: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.

requirements.value: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know the system.

map.value: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

short.value: If this coding was chosen directly by the user

definition.value: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).

comment.value: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.

requirements.value: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

map.value: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [ fhir:source "true"; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O ]

short.value: The total amount of radiation dose delivered for the course of therapy. (source: SNOMED, ASTRO)

definition.value: The total amount of radiation dose delivered for the course of therapy. (source: SNOMED, ASTRO)

definition.value: A decimal value.

Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.

map.value: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [ fhir:source "true"; fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O ]

short.value: A code explaining unplanned or premature termination of a plan of treatment, course of medication, or research study.

definition.value: A code explaining unplanned or premature termination of a plan of treatment, course of medication, or research study.
